fields.title: Walk to Golden Gate Bridge
fields.content: Outside of the Golden Gate Bridge, the quintessential SF tourist sites (Lombard St, Coit tower, Union Square, Powell st Cable Car, Ferry Building, Pier 39/FW) are walking distance. That being said the hills in SF can make a block seem twice as far. Also beware of the Tenderloin, one of the worst neighborhoods borders the most touristy area where most hotels are located - Union Square. My internal map of the Tenderloin is a triangle down Taylor St to Market, Market to Van ness and Van Ness to Geary and back to Taylor.

fields.title: Bernal Heights Park
fields.content: Bernal Heights Park is a good substitute for Twin Peaks, if you can't make it over there (like was the case for me and others). The view was nice from there, and you could see in all directions. Including being able to see(back then in 2014) the now demolished Candlestick Park.

fields.title: Land's End
fields.content:
Agreed on Land's End/Sutro Baths. I spent one Saturday of my trip to SF walking from the Ferry Building along the waterfront all the way to Land's End, stopping at Pier 39 and briefly to take pics of the Golden Gate before continuing my walk to Land's End and Sutro Baths. One of the best wandering adventures I've ever had while traveling.
Definitely needed an Uber to get back to the hotel in SOMA though... my feet were hurting! :P

fields.title: Michelin Star Restaurants
fields.content: SF is one of the top culinary hot spots on the planet. 3 restaurants are on the top 50 list (tied with NYC and London) and plenty more restaurants hold at least 1 Michillin stars. There is definitely a trickle down to the casual stuff, it's tough for anybody to survive the high rents without bringing their A game. Most of SFs neighborhoods have unique bars and restaurants to go to so there isn't a huge reason to seek a restaurant. I would star a bunch of these that sound good on google and if you are near it then munch away. Here's a list of some city hot spots and some of my fave:

fields.title: Coit Tower
fields.content: My family and I were pleasantly surprised walking up to Coit Tower. Unfortunately, due to it being the first day of our trip and just wandering around without cash, we didn't actually venture up the elevator to the top ($7 for non-residents, $5 for residents) but just the walk up to it was beautiful.

fields.title: Houses in SF
fields.content: The houses all the way up were magnificent and cute, their was beautiful nature all around you, friendly residents that we stopped and chatted to for a bit, and the view from the top, although covered by trees if you don't go up to the top of the tower, gave a good view of all the harbours, alcatraz, golden gate bridge (and my families other preferred bridge which I'm unsure what it was called), and IIRC the skyline of downtown San Francisco.

fields.title: Coit - Bernal
fields.content: Funny you mention Coit Tower. I wanted to go up to the top of that, but in 2014 walked to where that tower was located, only to find it was closed for some sort of renovations being done to the inside at that time. At least I did find a lot of other points in the city allowing for at least some sort of view, including Bernal Heights Park. Liked how you could see all over the city and beyond, from there.

fields.title: UT Campus
fields.content: The UT campus is very pretty and if you're looking for a nice place to take a walk in the evening I would highly suggest wandering around the grounds. If you're used to college campuses then it might be nothing special, but it's something I enjoy doing.

fields.title: 6th St No Go
fields.content: 6th street is, in my opinion, the worst part of Austin. It's dirty and just kind of gross with bad vibes. East 6th is the nicer part if you're looking for nightlife, but the city is full of a ton of nice bars to explore so going near 6th isn't even necessarily imo. Disclaimer, I'm not big on night life so I won't be able to answer many questions there.

fields.title: My Austin Favorites
fields.content:
The Capital also makes for a pleasant walk. It's a pretty building and is basically the gateway to downtown.

Zilker park is always worth a visit. Barton Springs is also worth it in the summer.

Food trucks, food trucks, food trucks. There are so many and they're are some really great ones, but they can get kind of expensive.

Austin is a fun city with a lot to do and plenty to eat. My favorite part about living here is the wide variety of good food we have.

fields.title: Hiking
fields.content: If you like hiking and own/rent a car, there are a plethora of sweet parks and hiking spots outside of town. My favorite was Goreman Falls, it's about a 1-1.5hr drive away from Austin. It has a unique waterfall that drips down a cliff that's covered in foliage.

fields.title: South Congress
fields.content:
Wander South Congress. There's still some cool shops holding out against the corporate interests. Grab a margarita at Guero's (careful they're strong). Ignore the trendy new stuff, and hit up Vespaio - amazing Italian for 20 years. Browse at Allen's boots, even if you aren't into Lucchese. If you want to buy some boots at a good value check out the Tecovas showroom on the Eastside (only open for a few hours on Saturday).
If you have a political leaning, check out The Cloak room - the bar is practically underground and spitting distance from the Capital. When the lege is in session, it's a great place to overhear gossip from all the staffers. The bartenders can tell some good stories - but good luck getting any names.

fields.title: Small Town Feel
fields.content: I moved to Austin 3 years ago and love it because it's a city where you find everything and yet have a small town feeling (compared to the major metropolis where I lived before). Fully agree with everything people said about the food and attractions. Although Oasis is overrated and the food is not the best, I still bring out of town friends & family for the sunsets. The view is pretty amazing.

fields.title: Getting Around
fields.content: As for public transit, it's not the greatest. Traffic on I35 is horrible, making the situation worse. Definitely stay somewhere between 183 and Ben white if you want to try to use the buses. Getting anywhere between south Congress and UT is the best situation to ride the bus. I would get the capmetro app to buy bus tickets on your phone; it makes it way easier. If you're the active type, the downtown/lake austin area can be fun to navigate by bike. Uber and lyft also get really expensive if you're on 6th or Rainey. I would take a bus to get a few stops away from those areas and then call an uber to save some money.

fields.title: Good Food
fields.content:
I went to Austin and few years ago and I ate at a restaurant called The Salty sow. It's highly irregular but I loved it so much I ate there a second time. Wonderful food!

I just spent 15 minutes on Google trying to refund the name of the restaurant so I could pass on the good word a how I love Austin for that place.

fields.title: Dev Down River
fields.content: I was also really impressed with the development of the south side of the river. There's some really nice condos going up, of vibrant active community that walks the dogs runs and bikes and also some hipster like shops South of downtown South of the river. I'm a fan of Austin even though I live in California

fields.title: Green Space
fields.content: Hong Kong is probably the densest city on the planet, and it's something you take note of immediately. Space comes at premium. That being said, it offers an unbelievably large amount of recreational green space. From Central (what could be considered the main financial district), you are able to take a boat to some outlying Village in the middle of nowhere. You wouldn't believe you were in Hong Kong. It's literally a small village where the people all know each other, and almost live a lifestyle that might have been present in rural China decade ago. Yet when you look up, you can see the towering skyscrappers in the far distant background. It's almost mind blowing.

fields.title: Favorite Markets
fields.content:
While I am not an expert, I have gone to Hong Kong several times over the last five years. I spent a month with my local friend a few years back and was there last fall.

One of my favorite things to do is visit the markets. It can be overwhelming but if you love people watching and just experiencing another culture I totally recommend it.

My favorite is Temple Street Night Market. There's tons of merchandise for sale and there's great little eateries lined along Temple Street. You pick out some fresh seafood from bins and they cook it up for you. A friend who's a restauranteur and chef in HK took me here and ever since then I go back.

fields.title: Housing
fields.content:
Firstly, housing is extremely expensive in Hong Kong but the student residences are very cheap. An appartment in the city will usually be around US$ 600 upwards per month while you pay the same for the entire semester in the student resisdences. The residences are therefore in very high demand, so apply as soon as you can.

secondly, although Hong Kong used to be an English colony, not everyone can speak english. In fact many of the students will give you a puzzled look if you try talking to them in English. It's not a problem because there are enough students who can speak the language properly, but just something you should be aware of. In the rest of the city people very rarely speak english properly, but often good enough so you can use stores and restaurants.

fields.title: Too Hot
fields.content: If you do plan on going during the summer, for most it is disgustingly hot. You may also have to bring a sweater or something along those lines for indoors as you will notice a drastic drop in temperature whenever you enter an air-conditioned building. I noticed that every time I return to HK, I can get sick because of the temperature fluctuations.

fields.title: Deals and Refunds
fields.content:
Refunds on Oyster.

After your trip you can refund any unused PAYG cash and the £5 deposit on one of the large machines in any tube station. Tap the card on the yellow pad, select refund, tap again and watch the cash flow...

It's the nearest I've ever got to playing slots and it's very exciting. I've been rounding up all my old oyster cards and cashing them in... ok, I'm sad...


I've wanted a London app like this for awhile. I'm in London 1-2 weeks at a time totaling about 2-3 months a year. We're often entertaining guests and up and out late at night. The app stores says its no longer available in the American Store. I can look it up but when I try to download it, I get an error message. Any suggestions?

fields.title: Big Ben
fields.content:
Just to let you know before you get there and are disappointed, Big Ben is currently having a lot of work done and covered in scaffolding. You can't see anything but a single clock face. :(

Still worth going to see the sights in that area. See The Palace Of Westminster (Parliament), Westminster Abbey, and then walk down Whitehall past all the monuments and Downing Street (where the prime minister lives), through Horseguards Parade and into St James Park on your walk to Buckingham Palace.

fields.title: Tea at Museum
fields.content: I would suggest getting afternoon tea and going to a museum. I highly recommend Bea's of Bloomsbury's St. Paul location (delicious and inexpensive - you can do "cream tea" for just a scone and tea or "afternoon tea" for all sorts of goodies), and then walking across the Millenium Bridge to the Tate Modern. (The big museums in London are free, so you don't have to budget for tickets or dedicate a certain amount of time to make sure you get your moneys worth.)

fields.title: Walking Tours
fields.content:
I did the free walking tour of west London and the street art walking tour with Strawberry Tours and they were absolutely fantastic. The two guides I had were very knowledgeable and quite a pleasure to walk with and listen to.

I spent a quiet afternoon walking in Highgate Cemetary and the surrounding park which was very nice and peaceful. Karl Marx and Douglas Adams are buried here. I would recommend this if you want something quite serene and relaxing.

fields.title: Hostels
fields.content: I found this thread looking for hostel advice...went with Clink78 based on comments like this and I have to say I was SO disappointed. Location is great, price is good, and staff was friendly, but the room/bed/bathroom situations were AWFUL. I've stayed in hostels before and wasn't expecting anything luxurious but jesus, the way they cram people in there is outrageous. I literally didn't have enough floor space to open my luggage and I had to army crawl in and out of bed since the beds are flush against one another and almost touching both walls. There was little ventilation or temperature control so the room got really musty and stunk to high heaven. I cancelled my reservation early and left to Generator. I'm much happier, except that they don't allow outside food. It's clear you're not alone in having loved Clink78 - I just don't get it. To each his own I guess!

fields.title: Shoreditch
fields.content:
Definitely go to Shoreditch for the nightlife or if you like graffiti (take a graffiti walking tour if you are a fan).

'The City' is worth visiting (City of London is a smaller city inside London, with its own mayor) - you will find St Paul's, Museum of London (highly recommend), Barbican (go inside, find the lake), Royal Court of Justice (an excellent piece of architecture, and sometimes public is allowed inside) there. The City is also the 'suits' district, so avoid peak hours (morning, lunchtime, 5-6pm) or even better go during the weekend.

Not sure where you are from and know this trick, but remember to go off the larger streets into old narrow paths (central London is very safe), especially in the City. Also, look up. Eye level view is London today, while the second stories of the buildings and above reveal its history.

fields.title: Southbank
fields.content: Walk down Southbank (the royal festival hall to London bridge), it'll take you past the Tate modern, the globe theatre, borough market ( brilliant food there). London bridge isn't far from Shoreditch, and right by the station is the Shard. It's kind of expensive to go to the top (it's the tallest building in London) but the view is phenomenal. You can go up to the bar and restaurant for free. Then go to Covent Garden, there's a restaurant called the flat iron. It's a steak restaurant, they don't take bookings so its first come first served, their steak is £10 and then you buy sides for extra. They give you ice cream after for free. Honestly it's one of the best meals out I've had.
